newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian lending rate drops 50 bps to 10.9 pct.
newsitem.headline: Croatian lending rate drops 50 bps to 10.9 pct.

text.p: The Croatian average lending rate dropped 50 basis points to 10.9 percent on Wednesday amid abundant offer and diminishing demand, dealers said.
The day's trade was halved at 25.7 million kuna leaving almost a 100 million surplus on the supply side.
The Weighted call-money rate decreased the most, sinking a full percentage point to 8.5 percent since yesterday.
Term loans accounted for less than half the trade, their rates mostly unchanged.
Insurers rolled over their previous call money and one-week loans at a steady 9.0 percent rate.
Bankers charged 10 and 11 percent for one-week money and prolonged one- and two-month deals at 15 and 18 percent respectively.
The central bank calculated its kuna midrates for Thursday firmer at 3.5662 against the German mark and at 6.1367 aginst the dollar. -- Metka Jelenc, Zagreb Newsroom, 385 1 4557075
